WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 9, 1905.
COLES PASHA'S REPORT FOB 1904. Coles Pasha’s Report is as interesting as ever, 'as well arranged, and, happily, as outspoken, and as suggestive The author’s optimism never blinds him to the defects that are still to be found b the prison system, bat while he is thoroughly determined to point out its weaknesses, and shows a courageous readiness to confess that he has at times made too roseate forecasts of the results of legal reforms, he is no pessimist, and his annual reports have a special attraction to all who prefer ‘human documents,’ which reveal the personality of their author, to mere catalogues of statistics sandwiched between the dry crusts of unilluminating comment, with which the Egyptian public is sometimes regaled. After pointing oat that the large increase b the prison population for 1904 is doe to the working of the revised code, under which there is practically no delay when onoe sentence is passed. Coles Pasha notes that,b spite of legal obanges and the establishment of Markaz magistrates, there are still too many prisoners awaiting triaL In his opinion the procedure followed by the police in sending on arrested persons to the Parquet without the neceasary witnesses, is largely responsible for this excessive ratio of unsentenced prisoners. The petty thief taken flagrante delicto, instead of going before the police magistrate and getting his sentence asia England, is first sent before the Parquet, which has to consult the Casier Jadioiaire, summon the witnesses, and name* day for the trial. The ’dossier” system may be sure and safeguard persons who are innocent of the crime imputed to them, but it is an open question at to whether its slowness does not nullify the effect of its sureness. The certainty of acquittal is said by some to make prison life comparatively blithe end cheerful, but we should imagine that it must be most exasperating to be dismissed 'without a stain on your character' after awaiting trial in the most palatial gaol for six weeks or so. On the other, hand the number of prisoners appealing showed a decided diminution, thanks to the recent establishment of Assise Courts, which was doe to the recognition of the fact that the power of appeal had been grossly abased in the past. As regards the periods of imprisonment and the claasification of offences, it is interesting to note that while the number of prisoned who were confined for contraventions was reduced by over 50 %, there was a large increase of persons imprisoned for delits (misdemeanours). The increase of the prison population in 1904 is doe to the increase ot persons sentenood to terms of from one week to three months, imprisonment, and not, as was imagined, to any increase in the number of persons sentenced to longer periods. Indeed, the number of those sentenced to periods of 6 months or a year’s imprisonment, snd over, bears exactly the same proportion to the prison population as in 1903, and is only 1 % lower than in 1909. The passages in the report which deal with juvenile offenders are of such importance that they must be dealt with separately, and we pass on to the conduct of the prisoned. A marked increase of minor prison offences is noted for 1904, bat major offences can hardly be said to have increased, and the acts of violence and murderous assaults on police officials at Tourah, which at one time threatened to become unpleasantly numerous, shows at most gratifying diminution, which is ascribed by Coles Pasha to the establishment of the discipline gang, and to the fact that the convicts are now well aware that certain selected officials carry revolved and are ready to use them if necessary. Of the 67 prisoned who escaped, 19 are still at large. The prison punishments list shows a most satisfactory and continued decrease in the sentences of corporal punishment, which have fallen from 9i3 in 1903 to 70 during the pest year. Tho passages of this report and the report of Dr. Kirton, Principal Medical Officer to the Prisons Administration, which deal with the health of the prisoners, demand separate notice in our colunmns. We are glad to note that Coles Pasha pays a well-deserved tribute to the clerical staff of the administration for the care and thoroughness with which the tables acompanying the report have been prepared, and to read that the information famished in the Egyptian Prisons' Report does not now fall far short of the statistics published annually by European and Indian prison
ESPIONAGE ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER. Inhabitants in the country parts of Prance have remarked the presence of Urge numbed of vendors of images and of itinerant merchants generally. Three persons visit the villages in detail, and show marked predilection for local gossip. Such a phenomenon was observed on the eve of the war of 1870-71, and its reappearance at this moment is significant of the resumed activities of Germany. The pedlars are no doubt spies in the pay of the German Intelligence Department. Their business is to find out the local resources of the country, and to take note of the state of feeling of the inhabitants. Daring the great struggle of thirty years ago the spy, primed with local knowledge, played a large part in the military operations. A be lame of the village would often be sainted by name by a soldier wearing the Prussian uniform, who had perhaps occupied some position in the country before the outbreak of the war, and utilised his opportunities of seeing and hearing to the advantage of the conquerors. In view of this fact, it is, perhaps, not surprising that the peasants should be convinced that Germany contemplates some new mischief. On the other hand, the French are also preparing for the day of an heroic straggle whose proximity rests on the knees of the gods. It appears to be established that the Military Intelligence Department is, however, a very ineffective arm of the French But-major. It received its death-blow at the Dreyfus trial — that singular and disquieting symptom of official rottenness. The country, disgusted at the revelations of the uses made of the secret side of the service,practically acquiesced in its abolition. Its power and duties were generally transferred to the polios, who naturally are more occupied with ordinary affaire of criminality than with matters of political and military espionage. Moreover, the repression of spying and informing, when carried out under the organised system of Germany, is a difficult and almost impossible operation. A pedlar upon whose person is found a notebook containing general particular* about the country-side can hardly be held in prison as a spy dangerous to the national interests.
